conflictDescription: User Story A forbids automatic health data logging under normal conditions to respect privacy, while User Story B requires quick and reliable access to vital data for medical staff, implying continuous data availability. These two requirements contradict because one mandates disabling automatic logging, and the other necessitates constant data access.
userStoryASummary: As an informal caregiver, I want to disable automatic health data logging and manually control data sharing to respect client privacy preferences under normal conditions.
userStoryBSummary: As a developer, I want to build clinical integration tools that prioritize simplicity and reliability, enabling quick and distraction-free access to vital data for medical staff.
cluster: Balance patient autonomy with clinical access

conflictDescription: User Story A requires control over automatic health data logging and sharing to respect privacy, implying possible restriction or stopping of data sharing, while User Story B demands quick and distraction-free access to vital data, implying continuous and unrestricted data availability, creating a direct conflict between forbidding and mandating the operation.
userStoryASummary: As an informal caregiver, I want to control automatic health data logging and sharing to respect privacy while supporting ongoing care.
userStoryBSummary: As a developer, I want to build clinical integration tools that prioritize simplicity and reliability, enabling quick and distraction-free access to vital data for medical staff.
cluster: Balance patient autonomy with clinical access
